snippet.textDisplay:
I know that no one might read this but I can hope that maybe MatPat reviews the comments on this video specifically.

I LOVE your videos! I can't stress enough how much I respect what you do and feel like you truly have the well-being of content creators and the audience at heart and how interesting your videos are.

With that said, I do feel like you could have handled this interview a bit better. From the outset it seemed like you were asking the "tough questions" but there were several ways those questions could have been improved as well as ways you could have read your interviewee that would have made for significantly fewer awkward interactions. For example, your first "tough" question, I'll paraphrase of course, came across to me like "Gamers feel like second class citizens. Is this feeling valid?" A better way to phrase it would probably have been something like "Sometimes it feels like Gamers are second class citizens on your platform due to X. Has this feeling been expressed to YouTube and if so, what ways has/is YouTube addressing these issues?"

Most of your questions felt like attacks when they didn't have to. That's the main point of that criticism. The second criticism I'd raise is the kind of poorly placed jokes between the questions. They honestly weren't needed and they caused, I feel, more animosity and had some argumentative and childish qualities to them. Now I understand that most of them were intended as jokes like the one about watching the ticking clock. Maybe this is my own interpretation but I get the feeling that Susan has been in the corporate world for so long that she was treating this like a corporate event. So she didn't have her playful, jokey hat on which made her a bit more defensive, especially with the ways you were asking some of the questions. Even the ones that came across as jokes felt almost half serious. That's what caused a lot of the tension that I would hope you felt at the time.

Again, this is not meant as some kind of scathing commentary but this really seemed like an opportunity to build a rapport between YouTube and gaming creators but you took it as more of an opportunity to hit her with your "tough journalistic questions." Hopefully some of this resonates with you, MatPat 😊
snippet.textOriginal:
I know that no one might read this but I can hope that maybe MatPat reviews the comments on this video specifically.

I LOVE your videos! I can't stress enough how much I respect what you do and feel like you truly have the well-being of content creators and the audience at heart and how interesting your videos are.

With that said, I do feel like you could have handled this interview a bit better. From the outset it seemed like you were asking the "tough questions" but there were several ways those questions could have been improved as well as ways you could have read your interviewee that would have made for significantly fewer awkward interactions. For example, your first "tough" question, I'll paraphrase of course, came across to me like "Gamers feel like second class citizens. Is this feeling valid?" A better way to phrase it would probably have been something like "Sometimes it feels like Gamers are second class citizens on your platform due to X. Has this feeling been expressed to YouTube and if so, what ways has/is YouTube addressing these issues?"

Most of your questions felt like attacks when they didn't have to. That's the main point of that criticism. The second criticism I'd raise is the kind of poorly placed jokes between the questions. They honestly weren't needed and they caused, I feel, more animosity and had some argumentative and childish qualities to them. Now I understand that most of them were intended as jokes like the one about watching the ticking clock. Maybe this is my own interpretation but I get the feeling that Susan has been in the corporate world for so long that she was treating this like a corporate event. So she didn't have her playful, jokey hat on which made her a bit more defensive, especially with the ways you were asking some of the questions. Even the ones that came across as jokes felt almost half serious. That's what caused a lot of the tension that I would hope you felt at the time.

Again, this is not meant as some kind of scathing commentary but this really seemed like an opportunity to build a rapport between YouTube and gaming creators but you took it as more of an opportunity to hit her with your "tough journalistic questions." Hopefully some of this resonates with you, MatPat 😊

snippet.textDisplay: Despite what was said in this video, I am worried that gaming channels like mine are put on the back burner and forgotten about. In fact you can no longer find my channel unless I share it directly.  I also think that with the new policy changes  gaming channels are going to have a new algorithm that will make it harder for us creators to exist on YouTube. The only thing that I got out of this interview is that YouTube only wants famous people who can make them more money. I don't know if my channel will survive the second round of policy and algorithm changes. I am trying to remain positive, but It is very difficult for me when I see CEOS who don't care.
snippet.textOriginal: Despite what was said in this video, I am worried that gaming channels like mine are put on the back burner and forgotten about. In fact you can no longer find my channel unless I share it directly.  I also think that with the new policy changes  gaming channels are going to have a new algorithm that will make it harder for us creators to exist on YouTube. The only thing that I got out of this interview is that YouTube only wants famous people who can make them more money. I don't know if my channel will survive the second round of policy and algorithm changes. I am trying to remain positive, but It is very difficult for me when I see CEOS who don't care.

snippet.textDisplay:
TL,DR:
"Instead of focusing on one major update at a time, we take the shotgun approach and pray to Clang that something sticks."
"We spend so much time talking to old politicians that we rarely have time to manually review things."
"We are selfaware enough to realize that our brand was basically built on the backs of Video Game related channels, especially with the first Minecraft boom."
snippet.textOriginal:
TL,DR:
 "Instead of focusing on one major update at a time, we take the shotgun approach and pray to Clang that something sticks."
 "We spend so much time talking to old politicians that we rarely have time to manually review things."
 "We are selfaware enough to realize that our brand was basically built on the backs of Video Game related channels, especially with the first Minecraft boom."

snippet.textDisplay: Nope.... so is it immoral to show violence in videos or is it against advertisement revenue? Is she saying that there aren't advertisers willing to provide adds for violent videos, or is youtube specifically ignoring that group of advertisers? Are they intentionally making this confusing and muddying the waters to use these rules as ways to threaten/demonetize whenever they want? Is this about morality or is it about money? If it's about both, where do you draw the line? Just nothing but distractions, and Pat tried, but he didn't get her where it mattered most in my opinion, not just for gaming, but for youtube in general, it's a dead platform, it is not where NEAR what it used to be 15 years ago.... It's dead and I am waiting for a viable alternative.

snippet.textDisplay:
Could the segregation of gamers on YouTube be the way that it is in order to highlight them as something different? (Like saying: we serve water, lemonade, and Pepsi products) it’s almost easier to separate then generalize it. This also means that its easier to give smaller YouTube categories the spotlight from this big entity that is YT gaming. Separating them almost helps gamers out, if you are a gamer you go to the gamer tab vs if you are looking for other stuff then the rest of the platform is open for that.

Correct me if I’m wrong, or provide thoughts below. I’d love to learn more about people’s opinions.
snippet.textOriginal:
Could the segregation of gamers on YouTube be the way that it is in order to highlight them as something different? (Like saying: we serve water, lemonade, and Pepsi products) it’s almost easier to separate then generalize it. This also means that its easier to give smaller YouTube categories the spotlight from this big entity that is YT gaming. Separating them almost helps gamers out, if you are a gamer you go to the gamer tab vs if you are looking for other stuff then the rest of the platform is open for that. 

Correct me if I’m wrong, or provide thoughts below. I’d love to learn more about people’s opinions.

snippet.textDisplay: I watched the entire video and I feel like all the answers Susan provided were dodging at worst, and unintentionally pointless at best. Rather than giving a straight forward answers, she told a story about how Youtube's system works. We know that. What we want to know is why your system isn't funtional anymore and weather or not your willing to fix it. It feels like she underestimated the entire gaming community, coming compleatly unprepared to answer any meaningful questions. MatPat poured his heart, soul, and passion into this interveiw and Susan just talked about advertizers, making money, and how, "Actually, we go above and beyond to fix x issue." It seems like she is compleatly unconcerned with all of the issues presented. Hopefully, in the future we'll see if she really cares or not.

snippet.textDisplay:
MATPAT PLEASE, PLEASE DO A DETAILED RESPONSE TO THIS VIDEO GOING THROUGH EVERYTHING SHE SAID.
I'm too tired to scroll, so I apologize if this has been said before, but around 8:18 Susan calls creators "endemic" which means a disease or illness. I am not sure how that was supposed to be construed, but it does not feel very cooperative. She also talks about the profanity regulations, specifically mentioning how there can be no profane language in specific parts of the video: "...they identified a few areas which is the whether or not there's profanity in the title, thumbnail, and whether or not there's a lot of profanity especially at the beginning of the video..." (25:01) Disregarding the terrible grammar and absolutely despicable sentence structure, that's the title, thumbnail, and beginning. They watch the first couple seconds of any given video and then move on. On the contrary: if creators just cuss the end of their video, they'll be fine. Also she should be calling it [Youtube] a community, not a "product."
snippet.textOriginal:
MATPAT PLEASE, PLEASE DO A DETAILED RESPONSE TO THIS VIDEO GOING THROUGH EVERYTHING SHE SAID. 
 I'm too tired to scroll, so I apologize if this has been said before, but around 8:18 Susan calls creators "endemic" which means a disease or illness. I am not sure how that was supposed to be construed, but it does not feel very cooperative. She also talks about the profanity regulations, specifically mentioning how there can be no profane language in specific parts of the video: "...they identified a few areas which is the whether or not there's profanity in the title, thumbnail, and whether or not there's a lot of profanity especially at the beginning of the video..." (25:01) Disregarding the terrible grammar and absolutely despicable sentence structure, that's the title, thumbnail, and beginning. They watch the first couple seconds of any given video and then move on. On the contrary: if creators just cuss the end of their video, they'll be fine. Also she should be calling it [Youtube] a community, not a "product."

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey Advertisers, think about this.

I watch YT-Content i want to watch, violence, etc. etc. included.
You withdraw your ads from those channels, because of said violence/etc.
Now, i don't see your ads, don't know your product, won't buy anything.

How did that help you?
I choose to watch that content, why would you not advertise through a channel i already love?
snippet.textOriginal:
*Hey Advertisers, think about this.*

I watch YT-Content *i* want to watch, violence, etc. etc. included.
*You* withdraw your ads from those channels, because of said violence/etc.
Now, i don't see your ads, don't know your product, won't buy anything.

*How did that help you?*
I choose to watch that content, why would you not advertise through a channel i already love?
